articles.headline: Goldman Sachs’s Tactic in Malaysian Fraud Case: Smear an Ex-Partner
articles.snippet: The investment bank is campaigning to convince the authorities that a former partner, Tim Leissner, was a master con man — and that is how the bank became ensnared in a vast fraud.
articles.abstract: The investment bank is campaigning to convince the authorities that a former partner, Tim Leissner, was a master con man — and that is how the bank became ensnared in a vast fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: They sound like the ingredients of a pulpy thriller: Bigamy. Secret religious conversions. A doctorate from a mail-order diploma mill. Affairs with powerful women.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Emily Flitter and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: French Government Calls for Carlos Ghosn to Be Replaced as Renault’s Leader
articles.snippet: If the carmaker ousts Mr. Ghosn, who is jailed in Tokyo on charges of financial impropriety, he would be separated entirely from the auto empire he created.
articles.abstract: If the carmaker ousts Mr. Ghosn, who is jailed in Tokyo on charges of financial impropriety, he would be separated entirely from the auto empire he created.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For nearly three months, as its chairman and chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, remained jailed in Tokyo on allegations of financial misconduct, the French carmaker Renault stood by him.

articles.headline: Government Shutdown Shakes Stability of Jobs That Are Often the Best Around
articles.snippet: Federal work is an anchor in many local economies, offering security and benefits increasingly rare in the private sector and a route to the middle class.
articles.abstract: Federal work is an anchor in many local economies, offering security and benefits increasingly rare in the private sector and a route to the middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: Verla Bloomfield has the kind of workplace that seems plucked from a different era. She has a pension, a union, several weeks of vacation and a paycheck that has nearly doubled in 14 years. Her employer? The United States government.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Microsoft Pledges $500 Million for Affordable Housing in Seattle Area
articles.snippet: The move is the most ambitious effort yet by a tech company to fund construction for local teachers, firefighters and other middle- and low-income residents.
articles.abstract: The move is the most ambitious effort yet by a tech company to fund construction for local teachers, firefighters and other middle- and low-income residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The Seattle area, home to both Microsoft and Amazon, is a potent symbol of the affordable housing crisis that has followed the explosive growth of tech hubs. Now Microsoft, arguing that the industry has an interest and responsibility to help people left behind in communities transformed by the boom, is putting up $500 million to help address the problem.

articles.headline: In a West Wing in Transition, Trump Tries to Stand Firm on the Shutdown
articles.snippet: Despite his public bravado, President Trump has had moments of frustration as he takes in negative news coverage of the shutdown, pointing his finger at aides for not delivering the deal he wants.
articles.abstract: Despite his public bravado, President Trump has had moments of frustration as he takes in negative news coverage of the shutdown, pointing his finger at aides for not delivering the deal he wants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has insisted that he is not going to compromise with Democrats to end the government shutdown, and that he is comfortable in his unbendable position. But privately, it’s sometimes a different story.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Vanguard’s Jack Bogle Wasn’t a Billionaire. He Was Proud of That.
articles.snippet: The Vanguard Group founder set up his firm so investors in its mutual funds would own it. While business titans are often measured by the size of their assets, he said, “I don’t share those values.”
articles.abstract: The Vanguard Group founder set up his firm so investors in its mutual funds would own it. While business titans are often measured by the size of their assets, he said, “I don’t share those values.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2012, I called John C. Bogle to discuss his favorite subject: index funds and the plight of rank-and-file investors. He had urged me to reach out to him “anytime I needed him,” and I took him up on that offer regularly.

articles.headline: World’s Biggest Investor Tells C.E.O.s Purpose Is the ‘Animating Force’ for Profits
articles.snippet: A year after his annual letter to chief executives urged them to run their companies with the social good in mind, the BlackRock chief Larry Fink said they must step into a leadership vacuum.
articles.abstract: A year after his annual letter to chief executives urged them to run their companies with the social good in mind, the BlackRock chief Larry Fink said they must step into a leadership vacuum.
articles.lead_paragraph: Larry Fink, the investment manager who oversees nearly $6 trillion at BlackRock, set off a yearlong conversation among business leaders and policymakers last January when he wrote a letter to chief executives declaring that companies needed to do more than make profits.

articles.headline: Climate Change’s Giant Impact on the Economy: 4 Key Issues
articles.snippet: Many of the big economic questions in coming decades will come down to just how extreme the weather will be, and how to value the future versus the present.
articles.abstract: Many of the big economic questions in coming decades will come down to just how extreme the weather will be, and how to value the future versus the present.
articles.lead_paragraph: By now, it’s clear that climate change poses environmental risks beyond anything seen in the modern age. But we’re only starting to come to grips with the potential economic effects.

articles.headline: As Shutdown Drags On, Some Step Up to Help Unpaid Federal Workers
articles.snippet: Restaurants have fed them without charge. Banks have suspended late fees on their credit cards. And at airports, they’ve been offered hugs, encouragement and casseroles.
articles.abstract: Restaurants have fed them without charge. Banks have suspended late fees on their credit cards. And at airports, they’ve been offered hugs, encouragement and casseroles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the government shut down in late December, Morgan McKay offered free pizza and wine to furloughed and otherwise unpaid federal workers at her popular Denver restaurant, Oblio’s.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Julie Bosman and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Paramount Was Hollywood’s ‘Mountain.’ Now It’s a Molehill.
articles.snippet: After decades of nearly slapstick mismanagement — spinning off TV and missing the internet — the studio behind “The Godfather” is fighting for its life.
articles.abstract: After decades of nearly slapstick mismanagement — spinning off TV and missing the internet — the studio behind “The Godfather” is fighting for its life.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a legendary Hollywood battle, one filled with so much back-stabbing and subterfuge that Vanity Fair likened it to a horror movie: “‘Wall Street’ as directed by Hitchcock.”
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Brooks Barnes
